data.title: Residence Halls
data.text:
Built in 1897, Brigham Hall - the first building to be completed after the Seminary fire - was named for Mary Brigham, a former Seminary teacher who was also a proponent of the cottage housing system and who raised $3,000 for the College toward the construction of cottages. Brigham was slated to become the President of the College in 1889, but was killed in a train accident shortly before she was to take office. Brigham Hall was constructed with funds raised by the alums of New York and Brooklyn, and was the home of the College presidents from 1897 to 1909.

It is one of a trio of halls built in 1897 (Safford and Porter are the others). It houses 80 students in single, double and triple rooms on 4 floors and a basement. It faces the Gaylord Library opposite route 116.

Year Built: 1897

Pearsons Annex was built before 1810 and had been known as the "Brick Store." The college purchased it and converted it into a freshman house, and gave it a name formerly given to the house next door.

Year Built: 1810

Residence Hall Apartments

After your first year you will go through the annual housing lottery process and will have the option to live in one of our apartments. Please note that these apartments are subject to change. In order to choose an apartment you need to create a housing group and the apartment must filled to occupancy at all times. If you choose to live in one of the residence hall apartments you must purchase the full board plan. The same amenities are available in residence hall apartments as traditional residential rooms.

121 1837 (3 students)

123 Ham (4 students)

115 Torrey (3 students)

Non-Residence Hall Apartments

If you live in one of these non-residence hall apartment you have a choice of purchasing the full board plan or no board plan. If you do not choose the full plan and are a financial aid recipient, there may be a reduction in aid.

Non-residence hall apartments do not have in building laundry. Apartment residents have full access to college internet. Basement spaces in non-residence hall apartments are not available for storage needs. Only standard bedroom furniture is provided and students in those spaces must provide any additional furniture that is needed for common space. If furniture is left behind by other students, it is left for the next occupants to use. 57 College Street has designated rooms for commuting Frances Perkins students.

1 Faculty Lane

The housing options for Frances Perkins students reflect the philosophy that developing a campus life can be an important part of the undergraduate experience. Frances Perkins students who elect to reside on campus will be housed in 17 Morgan Street or 3 Park Street. Frances Perkins scholars can opt in to living in a traditional residence hall.

Residential Fellows (RFs) are student staff members who serve as mentors, role models, and community builders in the residence halls. RFs are typically in their junior or senior year, have previously served as a Resident Advisor, and have the community of the entire residence hall as their focus. As members of the Residential Life staff, RFs coordinate hall meetings, advise and mentor Resident Advisors, and assist in the organizing of programs and activities in the residence halls. RFs also work closely with the Resident Advisors to address hall and individual student concerns such as hallmate conflicts, personal crisis or academic issues. Each RF participates in significant training each year and can provide resource and referral information to all students in the hall.

Resident Advisors (RAs) are student staff who serve as peer mentors and coaches to the community. RAs partner with the residents they oversee to develop a sense of community responsibility for the general welfare of the floor and develop the floor into a welcoming, inclusive and friendly community. RAs both get to know the residents situated around them and work to help them get to know each other. RAs can be sophomores, juniors or seniors and are trained as peer mentors in community development, conflict management and resolution, programming, academic support, personal wellbeing issues and interpersonal skills. Along with these skills, RAs are knowledgeable about campus resources and can provide referrals and information. Most importantly, the RA is available to each member of the community for peer support. RAs are selected for their desire to work with other students to create a positive and caring living experience for all.
